Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: An online candidate forum for their district is streaming now.
Story: I stared at my phone, the group chat buzzing with messages from my family. “Don’t forget, we’re leaving for Grandma’s birthday dinner in an hour!” my older brother reminded me. As a sister, I knew how much these gatherings meant to everyone, especially Grandma, who always looked forward to having us all together. I could already picture her smile, the laughter, the warmth of being surrounded by family. But as I glanced at my laptop, the live stream of the candidate forum for our district was about to begin. I’d promised myself I’d be more involved this year—read up on the issues, ask questions, and vote responsibly. My friends and neighbors counted on people like me to help shape our community. The pressure built inside me, tugging me in two directions. I wanted to be present for my family, to be the supportive sister they expected. But I also felt the weight of my responsibility as a citizen, knowing that my voice mattered. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out how to be both, feeling the tension rise with every passing minute.
